title: 107_s2902
content: The Act is titled the "Mathematics and Science Education Excellence Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Mathematics and Science Education Excellence Act" aims to elevate the status of math and science teaching by improving teacher education, focusing on continuous professional development, and fostering collaboration between teachers and experts in the field. The "Mathematics and Science Education Excellence Act" aims to enhance teaching skills, develop rigorous curricula aligned with State standards, and conduct research to improve student achievement in math and science. The Act defines key terms such as Director, elementary school, institution of higher education, and secondary school. During fiscal years 2003-2004, the Director will implement a mathematics and science partnership program through competitive grants to eligible partnerships. In fiscal years 2005-2007, the program will be carried out through grants to State educational agencies. The Director will implement a mathematics and science partnership program through competitive grants to eligible partnerships. A plan for joint administration will be prepared within 120 days of enactment, and technical assistance will be provided to meet program requirements. The program aims to support high-quality activities through grants or subgrants. Establishment of research on mathematics and science learning and education improvement. The Director will award grants to eligible recipients for research in cognitive science, education, and related fields to improve teaching and student achievement in mathematics and science in low-performing schools. Eligible recipients include institutions of higher education, nonprofit organizations, or consortia. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Director. The Director evaluates grant applications based on the recipient's ability to conduct research effectively, experience in teaching and learning science, and capacity to attract support for graduate programs. The Director evaluates grant applications based on the recipient's ability to conduct research effectively, experience in teaching and learning science, and capacity to attract and provide support for graduate students pursuing research at the intersection of educational practice and basic research on human cognition and learning. One of the grants awarded by the Director includes evaluating the effectiveness of current mathematics and science teaching practices. Recipients of grants must involve elementary and secondary school administrators and math and science teachers in their research, and submit the results to the Director for coordination with the Secretary. The Director shall coordinate with the Secretary of Education and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy in carrying out research grants, disseminating results to teachers, and providing support to improve teacher performance in the classroom. $12,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003. For fiscal year 2003, $12,000,000 is allocated for this section, with additional funding as needed for future fiscal years. SEC. 6. DUPLICATION OF PROGRAMS. The Director will review existing education programs at the National Science Foundation to eliminate any duplicative programs and ensure compliance with the provisions of this Act. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy will annually submit a report to specific congressional committees on the review of education programs at the National Science Foundation to ensure compliance with the provisions of the Act.
